titlStmt.titl: Solar Powered Oxygen Delivery: An Open-label Non-inferiority Comparison to Standard Oxygen Delivery Using Oxygen Cylinders
Solar Powered Oxygen Delivery: An Open-label Non-inferiority Comparison to Standard Oxygen Delivery Using Oxygen Cylinders

useStmt.restrctn: Author determines access on a case-by-case basis
Data-sharing agreement, including undertaking of confidentiality
useStmt.conditions: Access to deidentified data may be permitted to the general public. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access. A basic data sharing agreement form is required (ie. Agree to not attempt to re-identify the records so as to relate the information on the file to a particular person).

setAvail.accsPlac: Data is currently stored on Dr. Hawke's hard-drive.

stdyInfo.abstract: This is a randomized controlled trial to test the hypothesis that solar-powered oxygen delivery is noninferior to standard methods (oxygen from cylinders) for the supportive care of children with hypoxemia and respiratory distress. Demonstrating the utility of this technological innovation will represent an important step toward scale-up and implementation of reliable oxygen delivery in remote and resource-limited hospitals.

sumDscr.geogCover: Busoga, Jinja, Jinja Regional Referral Hospital
sumDscr.universe: Children under 13 years of age admitted to the hospital with hypoxemic respiratory illness.

dataColl.sampProc: There were 130 study participants in this prospective parallel open label randomized controlled trial.
dataColl.frequenc: Data was collected at baseline and every four hours until the end of hospitalization (usually 3 to 14 days). Biosamples were collected everyday.
dataColl.ConOps: Blinded double data entry and third person cross-validation were used.

source.dataSrc: Lambarene Organ Dysfunction Score (LODS); Respiratory Index of Severity in Children

othrStdyMat.relPubl: Nyende S, Conroy A, Opoka R. O, et al. Solar-powered oxygen delivery: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial. Trials. 2015; 16: 297.
Turnbull H, Conroy A, Opoka R. O, et al. Solar-powered oxygen delivery: proof of concept. The International Journal of Tuberculosis and Lung Disease. 2016, 20.5: 696.
